Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I glanced at my calendar, noticing the optional brainstorming session scheduled for tomorrow. As a software developer, I knew these sessions were where new ideas took root, and my team valued my input. Even if attendance wasn’t mandatory, I felt a responsibility to show up, collaborate, and help shape the next big feature. But just as I was about to RSVP, a notification popped up from my activist group: the petition to our state senator was closing in an hour, and this was my last chance to add my name. I’d spent weeks rallying support for this cause, urging others to take action. Now, when it mattered most, I was torn. If I signed the petition, I’d have to step away from the session, risking missing out on key discussions and letting my team down. If I stayed, I’d miss the opportunity to stand up for what I believed in. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations on both sides, feeling the pressure mount with every passing minute.
